{{EngvarB|date=April 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox person |name = James Duncan |image = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = 1834 |birth_place = [[Greenock]], [[Glasgow]], Scotland |residence = London, England |occupation = Sugar refiner, art collector |years_active = 1834–1905 | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1905|05|08|1834|01|11}} | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = |networth = |spouse = |website = |children = | parents = | religion = }} '''James Duncan''' (1834–1905) was a Scottish [[Sugar refinery|sugar refiner]] and businessman, who then became a philanthropist and art collector. His house and grounds in Glasgow became Benmore Botanic Garden, managed by Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh.
==Biography== Duncan was born in 1834 in Greenock. He was the son of a second-hand bookseller.<ref name=sugargiant>Philippe Chalmin {{Google books|bOPogF8v9-kC|The Making of a Sugar Giant: Tate and Lyle, 1859–1989|page=61}}</ref>
In the early 1850s, James Duncan was studying chemistry at Glasgow. He had a break and took a boat trip from Greenock to the lochs and coastlines of [[Argyllshire]]. While on [[Loch Long]], he conceived a unique method of refining sugar.<ref name=introduncan>{{cite web |url=http://www.rbge.org.uk/assets/files/Publications/Pages%20from%20jamesduncanbook0710-.pdf |title=Introduction to James Duncan |date=13 July 2010|publisher=www.rbge.org.uk | format=PDF |accessdate=6 January 2014}}</ref> He patented his idea for sugar refining. Then between 1858 and 1861, he became a partner of the Greenock firm of 'Duncan, Bell & Scott'.<ref name=sugargiant/><ref name=introduncan/> In 1854, the refinery was producing up to 50,000 tons.<ref>William H Marwick {{Google books|etRcAgAAQBAJ|Scotland in Modern Times|page=99}}</ref>
After 1861, he developed a factory in [[Silvertown]], London, at [[List of locations in the Port of London|Millbank]] 21 Mincing Lane,<ref name=roots>{{cite web |title= Topic: James Duncan of Benmore & Mary Moubray family |date=24 October 2008 |url=http://www.rootschat.com/forum/index.php?topic=336589.0 |publisher=rootschat.com |accessdate=4 January 2014}}</ref> called the 'Clyde Wharf Refinery'.<ref name=sugargiant/> It was the largest and most profitable sugar refinery in London.<ref name=introduncan/><ref name=sugarcane>{{cite journal |last=Martineau |first=George |date=February 1918 |title=Sugar cane and beet, an object lesson|url=https://archive.org/stream/sugarcanebeetobj00martuoft/sugarcanebeetobj00martuoft_djvu.txt |journal=Sugar Cane |volume=4 |accessdate=6 January 2014}}</ref> He was always refining the process and learning different applications to keep his company at the top of the industry. At the peak of the business, they were producing up to 2 thousand tons of sugar a week.<ref name=sugargiant/><ref name=sugarcane/>
In 1878 he was elected fellow of the [[Society of Chemical Industry]], later becoming its Vice-President. By 1879 he held the prestigious post of 'Chairman of the Sugar Refiners' Committee',<ref name=sugarcane/> and also became Vice-President of the 'Railway and Canal Traders' Union'.<ref name=introduncan/>
In 1884, cheap German sugar arrived in the UK, which was much cheaper than UK produced sugar.<ref name=roots/><ref name=sugarcane/>
In August 1885, he published an article in the 'Sugar Cane' journal, titled 'The bounty on exportation of refined sugar from the United States'.<ref>{{cite web |title=The bounty on exportation of refined sugar from the United States |url=http://search.socialhistory.org/Record/153891/Details |publisher=search.socialhistory.org |accessdate=6 January 2014}}</ref>
In 1886, the unfair foreign competition meant that he had to close his London works of Clyde Wharf.<ref name=sugarcane/>
He returned to Scotland, to manage the smaller refinery business in Greenock. After he retired, he spent time with his sister 'Mary Moubray' in [[Strone]], and then spent the winter months in Italy.<ref name=roots/>
==Philanthropy== James Duncan's charitable work was widely known throughout Britain. he gave 20 per cent of his annual £100,000 salary to a range of causes, making him one of the most committed [[philanthropists]] of the time.<ref name=sugargiant/><ref name=introduncan/><ref name=building>{{cite web |first=Mary| last=Gibby |url=http://www.buildingconservation.com/articles/benmore-fernery/benmore-fernery.htm |title=The Benmore Fernery |year=2013 |website=www.buildingconservation.com |accessdate=4 January 2014}}</ref><ref name=culture>{{cite web |first=Richard |last=Moss |title=Enlightened Victorian James Duncan comes home to the Benmore Botanic Garden in Argyll |date=14 March 2011 |url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/history-and-heritage/work-and-daily-life/rural-heritage/art349955 |publisher=culture24.org.uk |accessdate=15 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=scotsman>{{cite news |title=Philanthropist, tycoon and great Scot: James Duncan's time has come again |date=3 March 2011 |url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/philanthropist-tycoon-and-great-scot-james-duncan-s-time-has-come-again-1-1503538 |publisher=scotsman.com |accessdate=15 October 2014}}</ref>
He also built 2 churches for 2 different congregations.<ref name=sugargiant/>
He was known as a major collector of fine art and was also a lender of pictures to annual exhibitions, including the [[Royal Glasgow Institute of the Fine Arts]]. In 1878, he was elected Vice-President of the Royal Glasgow Institute of the Fine Arts. He regularly contributed works to European exhibitions, including the most prestigious at the [[Paris Salon]], and to key international exhibitions of art and industry in France and Germany in the 1870s and 1880s.<ref name=introduncan/>
He was the first Scottish collector of an [[Impressionist]] work including purchasing in 1883, [[Renoir]]'s painting 'Bay of Naples'.<ref name=scotsman/> The painting was later lent to the [[National Gallery of Scotland]] by the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in New York (who now own it), for a summer exhibition about James Duncan's collection.<ref name=roots/> Duncan was also one of the most valued and important clients of the influential French picture dealer [[Paul Durand-Ruel]], and regularly frequented the studios of Europe's most famous painters.<ref name=introduncan/> He collected works by the likes of [[Raeburn]] and [[Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot|Corot]],<ref name=building/> including [[Eugène Delacroix]]'s masterpiece ''Death of Sardanapalus'.<ref name=culture/>
He was friends with various people in different fields of work including; the chemist [[James Young (Scottish chemist)|James "Paraffin" Young]], who established the world's first commercial oil works; the pioneering ophthalmic surgeon 'Dr Neven Gordon Cluckie', whose work led to the establishment of eye surgeries in hospitals throughout Britain; the celebrated preacher [[Charles Spurgeon]]; [[Henry Boyd (academic)|Rev. Henry Boyd]] (Principal of [[Hertford College Oxford]], 1878–1922), with whom Duncan had worked closely in the 1870s to improve working conditions in London's East End; and [[Gustave Doré]], the French artist whose gallery, paintings and book illustrations proved so popular in Britain.<ref name=introduncan/><ref name=culture/> “Duncan also employed his significant wealth in helping the poor in Scotland and England and improving the working conditions of his workforce, building churches and schools, providing medical care and introducing an eight-hour working day." noted Peter Baxter (Benmore House Curator).<ref name=culture/>
Duncan had also been in contact with the eminent botanist [[Sir Joseph Dalton Hooker]] and with [[Henry Morton Stanley]], the explorer and friend of [[David Livingstone]] who visited Duncan some time in the 1870s or 1880s.<ref name=introduncan/>
In [[Kilmun]], at Graham's Point there is a memorial to James Duncan. Which was designed by A. Macfarlane Shannon.<ref>{{cite web |title=Kilmun, Graham's Point, Memorial to James Duncan, Kilmun |url=http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/sc-50435-kilmun-graham-s-point-memorial-to-james-d |publisher=britishlistedbuildings.co.uk| accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref>
==Benmore House== In 1870, James Duncan purchased Benmore House near Dunoon, Argyll.<ref name=building/><ref name=benmore>{{cite web|first=Donald |last=Stalker |title=Transactions of the Highland and Agricultural Society of Scotland Plantations of the Estates of Benmore and Kilmun, Argyllshire |url=http://www.electricscotland.com/agriculture/page45.htm |publisher=electricscotland.com |accessdate=15 October 2014}}</ref> He then set about building a gallery (to showcase his large collection of fine arts. As well as a [[fernery]] and one of the largest greenhouses in Scotland.<ref name=culture/>
The estates amounted up to 12,260 acres of land. He made extensive improvements to the land. On some of which he grazed ''West Highland cattle'' and [[Scottish Blackface|blackfaced sheep]]. The sheep were first seen at the [[Paris International Exhibition of 1878]]. His flock of sheep gained awards at the annual exhibitions of the Highland and Agricultural Society of Scotland.<ref name=benmore/>
He also had over six million trees planted as part of the large landscape alterations he had designed. Including, commissioning features such as the 'Golden Gates'.Which were earlier shown at the Paris International Exhibition.<ref name=scotsman/>
Following the introduction of a German sugar bounty, Duncan had a massive loss of fortune and had to sell the estate in 1889.<ref name=building/>
It was acquired by the Young Family and later gifted to [[Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh]]<ref name=roots/> It is now the [[Benmore Botanic Garden]].
His art collection at Benmore was split up and sold, his paintings are now housed in some of world's greatest museums such as the [[Louvre]], the [[Belvedere, Vienna|Belvedere]] in Vienna, the [[Art Institute of Chicago]] and the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, which is home to four of Duncan's pictures.<ref name=roots/><ref name=scotsman/>

'''John Duncan Anderson''' {{post-nominals|country=NZL|MNZM|size=85%}} is a New Zealand businessman, author and celebrity speaker. He is the founder of the travel and leisure company [[Contiki Tours]].<ref>[http://contiki.co.nz/pages/1-about-contiki About Contiki]</ref> The company is now owned by Trafalgar Tours, itself a division of [[The Travel Corporation]]
==Personal life== Anderson was born in [[Wellington]], New Zealand in 1938.<ref>''Only Two Seats Left'', autobiography published in 2010</ref> He is married to Ali (Alison), a passenger who fell ill on one of Contiki's first tours. They have four children.
Anderson's parents divorced when he was five years old; he was raised primarily by his mother although maintained a good relationship with his father, a dentist who emigrated to England when he was a child.
Anderson emigrated to England in 1961, returning to New Zealand in 1979 with a wife and family. He lived in [[Auckland]] for many years and currently lives in [[Blenheim, New Zealand|Blenheim]], [[Marlborough Region|Marlborough]].<ref>[http://www.speakerlink.co.nz/PresentersProfileView.asp?pid=24 Speaker Link]</ref>
In the [[2012 New Year Honours (New Zealand)|2012 New Year Honours]], Anderson was appointed a [[New Zealand Order of Merit|Member of the New Zealand Order of Merit]] for services to tourism.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.dpmc.govt.nz/publications/new-year-honours-list-2012 | title=New Year honours list 2012|date=31 December 2011 | publisher=Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet | accessdate=8 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="NZ_Herald_10776022">{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10776022 |title=New Year's Honours: John Anderson |author=Wade, Amelia |date=31 December 2011 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=31 December 2011}}</ref>
==Overseas experience== In 1960 Anderson travelled to London, England where his father was living. Anderson planned his route to England to include many stopovers en route. As the president of his local [[Junior Chamber International|Jaycees]] association, Anderson contacted fellow presidents in the cities that he planned and received many offers to host him. In this way, Anderson was able to defray his travel costs considerably.
In his book ''Only Two Seats Left''<ref>[http://theartscentrebookshop.circlesoft.net/catalog/296020/14798 Autobiography Review]</ref> Anderson describes his travels with a mixture of awe and sense of adventure. This was Anderson's first travel outside of New Zealand which at that time had a population of just over 2 million.<ref>[1960 in New Zealand]</ref>
==The first tours== Arriving in England in 1962, Anderson set about planning a trip to see Europe however had only £25 to his name Anderson came up with the idea of advertising for 11 other young [[Australasia]]ns to join him on the trip. He worked out the total costs for the trip and then divided by 11, thus providing a free seat for himself.<ref>[http://www.celebspeakers.com/speaker/john-anderson/ ''Celebrity Speakers New Zealand'']</ref>
The trip sold quickly, assisted by Anderson meeting prospective fellow travellers and exaggerating his experience of Europe. In fact, his only previous experience of Europe was an overnight trip to Paris. Shortly after having sold all the seats, Anderson was approached by two more prospective passengers. Anderson decided to take advantage of the interest and advertise a second tour to operate following the first. This second tour also sold well and sold out before the first tour departed.<ref>[http://unlimited.co.nz/unlimited.nsf/growth/on-the-road-again Unlimited Magazine]</ref>
Despite Anderson's inexperience the tour was a success. Anderson admitted his lack of European knowledge to his customers on the first day. After that, he and the eleven others shared duties and decision making, including driving duties in the 12 seater Commer van they christened ''Tiki'' after the [[Tiki|Maori good luck charm]]
For the second tour Anderson had increased the price from £100 to £115 per person. Despite this, upon arrival in Monaco Anderson found he had nearly run out of money and would be unable to complete the advertised itinerary. Anderson worked out the amount of money that he would need to express the group directly back to England and took the remaining funds to a casino where he gambled on the [[roulette]] tables. He won and was able to continue the tour without his customers finding out.
==Contiki Holidays== The trips which had begun as an exercise to fund his own travels around Europe became a fast-growing business; fleet and staff grew rapidly and a number of new tours were developed under the name ''Tiki Tours'', in recognition of the company's first vehicle.
When the [[Tourism New Zealand|New Zealand Tourist Board]] challenged Anderson over his use of the name ''Tiki Tours'' he changed the company's name to ''Contiki'', the ''con'' coming from [[Continental Europe|The ''Con''tinent]].<ref>[http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2005/02/25/1109180077418.html Sydney Morning Herald]</ref>
Contiki grew to include tours worldwide. During the 1980s the company began to diversify from its roots as a tour company for 18- to 35-year-olds (originally 19 to 29). Examples included building hotel resorts in Queenstown and in the Great Barrier Reef, and the purchase of [[Fullers Ferries]].
By the mid 1980s Contiki was a global organisation headquartered in Hong Kong. Anderson was living in New Zealand and travelled frequently for directors meetings and to review the company's operations.
===Sale of Contiki=== In the early 1980s Anderson sold down his investment in Contiki, allowing fellow directors to invest as shareholders. In 1985 Omnicorp, a company controlled by [[Lloyd Morrison]] purchased a 50% stake in the business.
The [[Black Monday (1987)|stock market crash of 1987]] devalued many of Contiki's assets. This, along with the poor performance of recent acquisitions, notably Fullers Ferries, placed Anderson in financial difficulty. In 1989 he was forced to sell his remaining shares in Contiki as well as his family home to avoid bankruptcy.
==After Contiki== During the early 1990s Anderson was employed to sell off the assets of former Contiki empire. His wife Ali returned to full-time work to supplement their income. They briefly owned and ran a chain of stores<ref>[http://www.nileguide.com/destination/auckland/restaurants/global-sandwich/1013153 ''Global Sandwich'' review]</ref> in Auckland selling packaged sandwiches. The business was short-lived and they moved to Blenheim in the late 1990s. Along with Contours Travel, John has started tours to South America for 'baby boomers'.<ref>[http://www.celebrityspeakers.com.au/entrepreneur-speakers/john-anderson/ Speaker Profile of John Anderson at The Celebrity Speakers Bureau]</ref>
===Public speaking=== In recent years Anderson has taken up public speaking as a profession and has presented his Contiki story to many businesses.<ref>[http://www.celebspeakers.com/john-anderson/ Celebrity Speakers biography]</ref>
===''Only Two Seats Left''=== In 2010 Anderson published ''Only Two Seats Left'', an autobiography that focuses mainly on his time with Contiki from 1961 to 1989.

Momoh is of [[Etsakọ]] extraction. Momoh was brought up in [[Lagos State]], southwestern Nigeria and his father was a cook. Over the past decades, he has built a commercial [[satellite television|satellite television station]] with a reputable integrity in a country where the media sector is tainted by corruption.{{cite web|url=http://www.bdlive.co.za/africa/africanbusiness/2015/07/20/independent-nigerian-tv-channel-makes-airwaves|title=Independent Nigerian TV channel makes airwaves|work=Business Day|accessdate=14 August 2015}} John Momoh graduated from the [[University of Lagos]] with a bachelor's degree in Mass Communication and a master's degree in International Law and Diplomacy. He is a member of the [[International Academy of Television Arts and Sciences]] based in New York, and has served as a juror for the [[International Emmy Awards]].{{cite web | url=http://www.weforum.org/contributors/john-momoh | title=WEF - John Momoh | publisher=[[World Economic Forum]] | accessdate=3 January 2015 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150103090249/http://www.weforum.org/contributors/john-momoh | archivedate=3 January 2015 | df= }} He is also serving as a juror for the AIB Awards presented by the Association for International Broadcasters. He has been voted{{cn|date=November 2017}} the world's 250 top tax advisers since 2008.[http://www.taxdirectorshandbook.co.uk Tax Directors' Handbook]. Retrieved on 24 August 2011. He has been active in participating in public affairs since the 1990s to promote fair competition, the diversification of economy, responsible fiscal policy and housing policy, human rights and democratic reforms. He is a founding member of the Hong Kong Core Value Movement and the Synergynet. He is also a founding member and vice-chairman of the political think-tank, [[The Professional Commons]]. ==Education and professional qualifications== Leung was born in Hong Kong. He graduated from [[Queen's College, Hong Kong|Queen's College]] in 1981 before going on to the [[Hong Kong Polytechnic University|Hong Kong Polytechnic]], where he received a professional diploma in [[accountancy]]. He then went abroad for further studies, first for a [[Bachelor of Social Science|BSc]] in economics at the [[London School of Economics and Political Science]], graduating in 1987, and then an [[LL.M]] at the same institution, which he completed in 1992. Leung holds the professional qualifications of [[Fellow of the Society of Certified Practicing Accountants|FCPA]], [[Chartered Accountant]], [[Tax advisor#United Kingdom|UK Chartered Tax Adviser]], and Hong Kong Certified Tax Adviser. He is a solicitor admitted in England and Wales and in Hong Kong. {{cite news|title=Hong Kong chief executive Leung Chun-ying sues lawmaker for defamation|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/2076459/hong-kong-chief-executive-leung-chun-ying-sues-lawmaker|date=6 March 2017|newspaper=South China Morning Post}} ==In politics== He first contested and won in a [[Hong Kong Election Committee Subsector by-elections, 2005|by-election in 2005]] to fill a casual vacancy in the [[Election Committee#Accountancy|accountancy sub-sector]] of the [[Election Committee]] for the Chief Executive. In 2006, he participated in the sub-sector election (accountancy) for the Election Committee again and was elected with the second highest votes amongst the 20 successful candidates in that sub-sector. He nominated [[Lee Wing-tat]] and [[Alan Leong]] respectively in the [[Hong Kong Chief Executive election, 2005|2005]] and [[Hong Kong Chief Executive election, 2007|2007 Chief Executive Election]]. In 2011, he led a nine-member team, "Democratic Accountants", to take part in the Election Committee sub-sector election for a third time; all members were elected. He nominated [[Albert Ho]] to take part in the [[Hong Kong Chief Executive election, 2012|Chief Executive election in 2012]].{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} Later that year, he ran in the [[Hong Kong legislative election, 2012|LegCo election]] for the seat representing the [[Accountancy (constituency)|Accountancy constituency]]. He was elected with 7,701 votes, against 6,538 for Nelson Lam and 2,231 for other candidates.{{cite web|url=http://www.elections.gov.hk/legco2012/pdf/introd/C_01.pdf|title=Introduction to Candidates: Leung Kai-cheong Kenneth|publisher=Electoral Affairs Commission|location=Hong Kong|accessdate=25 August 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.elections.gov.hk/legco2012/eng/result/rs_fc_C.html|title=Election Results: Accountancy|publisher=Electoral Affairs Commission|location=Hong Kong|date=10 September 2012|accessdate=25 August 2013}} ==Controversies== In 2013, Leung was one of eight legislators treated by [[Cathay Pacific]] to a six-day trip to France to tour [[Airbus]] factories. In response to the public outcry and the perception of a [[conflict of interest]], Leung stated that he would donate HK$100,000 to [[UNICEF]], but refused to apologise.{{cite news|url=http://news.sina.com.hk/news/20130825/-2-3050243/1.html |title=梁繼昌捐10萬拒道歉 (Leung Kai-cheong will donate $100k, refuses to apologise) |work=[[Ming Pao]] |date=25 August 2013 |accessdate=25 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407074742/http://news.sina.com.hk/news/20130825/-2-3050243/1.html |archivedate= 7 April 2014 |df= }} In March 2017, Kenneth Leung was sued by [[CY Leung]], the Chief Executive of Hong Kong, for alleged defamation. Kenneth Leung has made remarks about the $50 million payment that CY Leung received from an Australian firm in 2011 for signing a non-compete agreement, claiming that CY Leung is under investigation by overseas tax authorities for that payment, which CY Leung denied.http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/2076459/hong-kong-chief-executive-leung-chun-ying-sues-lawmaker According to [[SCMP]], Kenneth Leung said that the lawsuit "would not stop him from continuing with a Legislative Council investigation into the payment controversy".http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/2076459/hong-kong-chief-executive-leung-chun-ying-sues-lawmaker ==Other government and professional activities== As of 2013, Leung is a member of the [[Hong Kong Housing Authority]] (since 2007),[http://www.hongkonghousingauthority.gov.hk Hong Kong Housing Authority]. Retrieved on 24 August 2011. the [[Independent Police Complaints Council]] (since 2011),[http://www.ipcc.gov.hk Independent Police Complaints Council ]. Retrieved on 24 August 2011. and the [[Estate Agents Authority]] (since 2010).[http://www.eaa.org.hk Estate Agent Authority]. Retrieved on 24 August 2011. He has previously been a member of the Inland Revenue Board of Review and the Estate Agents Authority's Disciplinary Committee. Leung also plays a role in a number of industry and professional groups, He was vice-chairman of the Taxation Policy Committee of [[The Taxation Institute of Hong Kong]] before rising to the chairmanship in 2008.[http://www.tihk.org.hk The Taxation Institute of Hong Kong]. Retrieved on 24 August 2011. He has been the vice-chairman of [[The Professional Commons]] since 2007.[http://www.procommons.org.hk The Professional Commons]. Retrieved on 24 August 2011. He continues to be a member of the Joint Liaison Committee on Taxation (since 2007) and the tax sub-committee of the Hong Kong chapter of the Alternative Investment Management Association, Hong Kong Chapter (since 2007).[http://hongkong.aima.org The Alternative Investment Management Association, Hong Kong Chapter]. Retrieved on 24 August 2011. He was formerly a member of the Public Affairs Form and an external examiner for the PCLL courses of the [[University of Hong Kong]] and the [[City University of Hong Kong]]. He has published articles in international professional journals including ''International Tax Review'', ''Asia-Pacific Journal of Taxation'', ''China Tax'', and ''China Staff''. He is a regular contributor to the column in [[Hong Kong Economic Journal]], the Professional Eye. ==Personal life == Leung is short-sighted, with one eye much worse than the other. In 2013, doctors found damage to the [[retina]] of his right eye, which if it worsened could have led to [[retinal detachment]], and he underwent surgery to correct the problem.{{cite news|url=http://news.sina.com.hk/news/20130813/-2-3040348/1.html |title=梁繼昌扮酷有苦衷 |work=[[Ming Pao]] |date=13 August 2013 |accessdate=13 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140726033815/http://news.sina.com.hk/news/20130813/-2-3040348/1.html |archivedate=26 July 2014 |df= }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://kennethleung.hk/wp/ Official website] *[http://www.legco.gov.hk/general/english/members/yr12-16/lk.htm Biography] {{s-start}} {{s-par|hk}} {{s-break}} {{s-bef|before=[[Paul Chan (Hong Kong legislator)|Paul Chan]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Member of Legislative Council|district=[[Accountancy (constituency)|Accountancy]]|years=2012–present}} {{s-inc}} {{S-prec}} {{S-bef|before=[[Leung Che-cheung]]

('''LDC''') is a global merchant firm that is involved in [[agriculture]], [[food processing]], international shipping, and finance. The company owns and manages hedge funds, [[Ship management|ocean vessels]], develops and operates telecommunications infrastructures, and it is also involved in [[real estate]] development, management and ownership.{{cite web|title=Groupe Louis Dreyfus S.A. - Company Profile, Information, Business Description, History, Background Information on Groupe Louis Dreyfus S.A. |url=http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/history2/66/Groupe-Louis-Dreyfus-S-A.html|accessdate=7 April 2015}} It is one of the "ABCD" quartet of companies - alongside [[Archer Daniels Midland]], [[Bunge Limited|Bunge]] and [[Cargill]] - that dominates world agricultural commodity trading.{{cite web|title=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/26/louisdreyfus-results-idUSL6N0WK3JZ20150326|website=Reuters|accessdate=26 March 2015}} The company makes up about 10% of the world's agricultural product trade flows, and it is the world's largest cotton and rice trader.{{cite web|title=Bloomberg|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-09-18/louis-dreyfus-appoints-ceo-as-billionaire-owner-tightens-grip|website=Bloomberg|accessdate=18 September 2015}} It is also regarded by many as the second-largest player in the world's sugar market.{{cite web |title=reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/17/sugar-cargill-dreyfus-idUSL1E8GH00420120517|website=Reuters|accessdate=16 May 2012}} LDC Metals expanded to become the world’s third biggest trader of copper, zinc and lead concentrate, behind only [[Glencore]] and [[Trafigura]].{{cite web|title=FinancialTimes|url=https://www.ft.com/content/1d784a12-5c0f-11e7-b553-e2df1b0c3220|website=FinancialTimes|accessdate=28 June 2017}} Louis Dreyfus Company has its head office in [[Rotterdam]] in the [[Netherlands]]. The company's parent, Louis Dreyfus Holding B.V., has its headquarters at the [[World Trade Center (Amsterdam)|World Trade Center]] in [[Amsterdam]]."[http://www.louisdreyfus.com/contacts/overview.html Contacts] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019142440/http://www.louisdreyfus.com/contacts/overview.html |date=2012-10-19 }}." Louis Dreyfus Group. Retrieved on October 30, 2012. "WTC Amsterdam Tower H - Level 25 Zuidplein 208 1077 XV Amsterdam The Netherlands" Louis Dreyfus companies are present in more than 100 countries, with 72 offices. Major offices are located in [[Geneva]], [[London]], [[Beijing]], [[Buenos Aires]], [[Paris]], [[São Paulo]], [[Singapore]], [[New York City]] and [[Connecticut]].{{cite web|title=Louis Dreyfus|url=http://www.internhere.com/Employer/Louis_Dreyfus_1063|website=Intern Here|accessdate=7 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150413194651/http://www.internhere.com/Employer/Louis_Dreyfus_1063|archive-date=2015-04-13|dead-url=yes|df=}} Aggregate average annual gross sales in recent years have exceeded $120 billion. The company employs more than 22,000 people globally at peak season. == History == In 1851, the company was founded in the [[Alsace]] region of [[France]] by [[Léopold Louis-Dreyfus|Léopold Dreyfus]], the 18-year-old son of a farmer from [[Sierentz]], under the name of his father, Louis Dreyfus. Léopold purchased wheat from local farmers in Alsace and transported it to [[Basel]] in [[Switzerland]], {{convert|8|mi|km|order=flip}} away.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ldcom.com/global/en/about-us/our-heritage/|title=Louis Dreyfus Company :: Our heritage|website=www.ldcom.com|access-date=2016-09-08}} Léopold developed a fortune whilst still a teenager through cross border cereal trading. He rapidly diversified across shipping, [[weapons manufacturing]], agriculture, oil and banking, thus establishing one of the wealthiest dynasties in Europe.''Saatchi & Saatchi: The Inside Story'', By Alison Fendley, page 100, Arcade Publishing, 8 Oct 1996 His descendants still own the company to this day. By the early 20th century, the Louis-Dreyfus family was described as one of the "top five biggest fortunes of France". However, as a [[Jewish]] family during the Second World War much of the family assets were confiscated by the [[Vichy government]] and some members of the family fled to America.''The History of Foreign Investment in the United States, 1914-1945'', Harvard University Press, 2004, By Mira Wilkins, page 479 Léopold Louis-Dreyfus's great-grandson, [[Gérard Louis-Dreyfus]], was chairman of '''Louis Dreyfus Energy Services''', a subsidiary of the group involved in [[crude-oil trading]], gas investments and infrastructure. Gérard is also the father of American actress [[Julia Louis-Dreyfus]], the Emmy-winning star of ''[[Seinfeld]]''. Another branch of the dynasty, based in Paris, was headed by [[Robert Louis-Dreyfus]] (who was also the CEO of [[Adidas]]) until his death in 2009. It is currently overseen by his widow, Russian-born [[Margarita Louis-Dreyfus|Margarita Bogdanova Louis-Dreyfus]].{{cite web|last1=Bermant|first1=Yoel|title=Margarita Louis-Dreyfus, Head of Louis Dreyfus Holdings, Is Winning the Battle to Keep the Company in Family branch of the family's business is headed by Philippe Louis-Dreyfus (born 1945) and is concerned primarily with offshore industrial activities and freight shipping operations.{{cite web|title=Board of '''Malcolm Arthur Brinded''' CBE (born 18 March 1953) is a British businessman, and former Executive Director for [[Upstream International]] and Executive Board Member of [[Royal Dutch Shell plc]] and a Non-Executive Director of [[Network Rail]].
==Career== Brinded graduated from [[Cambridge University]] with a degree in Engineering in 1974,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=5106406&ticker=RDSA:LN|title=Malcolm Brinded: Executive Profile & Biography|work=investing.businessweek.com}}</ref> and joined Shell in The Hague. Since then he has worked for the Shell Group in [[Brunei]], the [[Netherlands]], [[Oman]] and the UK.<ref name="fo">{{cite web|title=Malcolm Brinded Profile|url=https://people.forbes.com/profile/malcolm-brinded/69076|work=people.forbes.com}}</ref>
Having joined Shell in 1974<ref name="fo"/> from 1998 he was Managing Director of [[Shell UK Exploration and Production]], in 1999 he became Shell Country Chairman in the UK,<ref name="sh">{{cite web|url=http://www.shell.com/home/content/aboutshell/who_we_are/leadership/executive_committee/malcolm_brinded/|title=Malcolm Brinded|work=www.shell.com}}</ref> in 2002 he became a managing director of Royal Dutch, and from 2004 was Managing Director of Shell Transport. In October 2004 he became an Executive Director of Royal Dutch Shell in charge of Exploration & Production.<ref name="fo"/>
Malcolm is a Fellow of both the [[Institution of Civil Engineers]] and of the [[Royal Academy of Engineering]].<ref name="sh"/> He is a member of the Nigerian President’s Honorary International Investor Council and a Trustee of the [[Emirates Foundation]] and the [[International Business Leaders Forum]]. He is the former Chairman of the [[Shell Foundation]].<ref name="fo"/>
In 2002, Brinded was awarded the honour of the [[CBE]] in the New Year's Honours List for services to the UK oil and gas industry
On 11 October 2010, Malcolm Brinded was appointed as a Non-Executive Director of [[Network Rail]], subject to being confirmed to the post by election by Network Rail's members at the 2011 AGM, a position he held until November 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard-business/article-23886909-shells-malcolm-brinded-moves-to-network-rail-board.do|title=Shell's Malcolm Brinded moves to Network Rail board|date=12 October 2010|work=www.thisislondon.co.uk|publisher=London Evening Standard}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.networkrail.co.uk/feeds/network-rail-appoints-non-executive-directors-to-board/|title=Network Rail Appoints Non-executive Directors to Board|date=23 November 2016|work=Network Rail Website}}</ref>
Malcolm Brinded was elected as President of the [[Energy Institute]] on 4 July 2017.
==Family== Brinded is married to Carola and has three sons, the eldest of whom, Benjamin Brinded, followed in his father's footsteps to [[Cambridge University]], where he became President of the Students' Union.

{{globalize|date=October 2012}} A '''merit shop''' is term which refers to a firm or organization without a labor union. Management retains the right to perform hiring, promotion, salary adjustments, bonuses and termination based on the laws of the state and federal government, along with its evaluation of individual's ability to accomplish the tasks assigned to them by the employer. By Law, these decisions will not be biased by age, race, national origin, organizational affiliation, seniority, color, creed and sex. The term "Merit Shop" was coined by John Trimmer, who served from 1952 to 1976 as an officer of the [[Associated Builders and Contractors]], an American trade association consisting primarily of non-union construction contractors. In common usage, "merit shop" is often synonymous with being non-union or [[open shop]].
There are many other organizations that represent merit shop companies. For example, the [[Independent Electrical Contractors]] represents almost 3,000 open shop electrical and systems contractors in the USA, while also offering apprentice training, as recognized by the Department of Labor. Founded in 1957, the organization represents its member companies' small business and merit shop interests at the national, state, and local levels of government.
Other merit shop-oriented associations include the [https://web.archive.org/web/20080115192502/http://www.meritshopcraftsmen.com/ Association of Merit Shop Craftsmen] and the Merit Shop Roundtable.
A definition provided in ''Merriam-Webster's Dictionary of Law'' (1996) defines "merit shop" as a noun meaning “[[open shop]].”

200 m – 20.5 (1956)[http://trackfield.brinkster.net/Profile.asp?ID=52&Gender=M Michael Agostini]. trackfield.brinkster.net | medaltemplates= {{Medal|Country|{{flag|Trinidad and Tobago|colonial}}}} {{Medal|Competition|[[Commonwealth Games]]}} {{Medal|Gold | [[1954 Commonwealth Games|1954 Vancouver]] | 100 yd}} {{Medal|Bronze | [[1958 Commonwealth Games|1958 Cardiff]] | 100 yd}} {{Medal|Competition|[[Pan American Games]]}} {{Medal|Silver| [[Athletics at the 1955 Pan American Games|1955 Mexico City]] | 100 m}} {{Medal|Bronze| [[Athletics at the 1955 Pan American Games|1955 Mexico City]] | 200 m}} {{Medal|Country | {{flagIOCteam|BWI|1960 Summer}} }} {{Medal|Competition|[[Pan American Games]]}} {{Medal|Silver| [[Athletics at the 1959 Pan American Games|1959 Chicago]] | 100 m}} {{Medal|Bronze| [[Athletics at the 1959 Pan American Games|1959 Chicago]] | 200 m}} {{Medal|Bronze| [[Athletics at the 1959 Pan American Games|1959 Chicago]] | 4×100 m }} }} '''Michael George Raymond Agostini''' (23 January 1935 – 12 May 2016) was a Trinidadian [[track and field]] athlete. He was the first athlete from his country to win a [[gold medal]] at what is now known as the [[Commonwealth Games]], when he won the [[Athletics at the 1954 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|100 yards final]] in [[Vancouver]], British Columbia, Canada, on 31 July 1954.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/sport/more-sports/former-champion-sprinter-mike-agostini-has-died-at-the-age-of-81/news-story/929d54f89ee4d34b8401483974a37e7c |title= Former champion sprinter Mike Agostini has died at the age of 81 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=12 May 2016 |accessdate=17 May 2016 |author= Mike Hurst, David Tarbotton}} == Early life == Michael Agostini was born on 23 January 1935 at [[Port-of-Spain]], Trinidad. His family had interests in sports: his father played football, his mother played hockey, and all his siblings participated in football and athletics events at St. Mary's College, where they studied.{{cite web|url=http://legacy.guardian.co.tt/archives/2004-12-02/SA-7.html |title=Agostini’s gold – T&T’s first |author=Bernard Linley |date=1 December 2004|work=The Trinidad Guardian |accessdate=16 May 2016}} == Athletics career == Agostini participated in athletics, football, and boxing in his school days. In 1952, at Kingston, he defeated Jamaican sprinter [[Herb McKenley]], who had won one gold and two silver medals at the [[1952 Summer Olympics|1952 Helsinki Olympics]]. On a scholarship, Agostini enrolled at [[Villanova University]], where he received training from [[Jumbo Elliott (coach)|Jumbo Elliott]]. On 23 January 1954, his 19th birthday, he set a world indoor record for over 100 yards at Washington, beating Olympic champion [[Lindy Remigino]]. The same year, he competed in the [[1954 Commonwealth Games]] at Vancouver, Canada, and won gold in the 100 yards race (9.6). He defeated Canadian [[Don McFarlane]] (9.7) and Australian [[Hec Hogan]] (9.7), becoming the first athlete from Trinidad and Tobago to win gold at the Commonwealth Games. Hogan was then in the news for tying the world records of 100 yards (9.3) and 100 m (10.2) and was the most anticipated winner. Reports suggest that Hogan's performance was hampered after he was informed that Agostini had ironically stated in a pre-Games interview, "Who the heck is Hogan?" when questioned about him. In 1955 Agostini participated in the [[Pan American Games]] [[Athletics at the 1955 Pan American Games|held in Mexico]] and won a silver and a bronze in the 100 m and 200 m races, respectively.{{cite web|url= http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/pag.htm |title= Pan American Games | accessdate=17 May 2016}} He also won silver at the [[Athletics at the 1959 Pan American Games|1959 Chicago Pan American Games]] in the 100 m, a bronze in the 200 m, and another bronze in the 4 × 100 m relay. In the next [[Athletics at the 1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|Commonwealth Games at Cardiff]] in 1958, he stood third in the 100 yards run behind [[Keith Gardner]] of Jamaica and [[Tom Robinson]] of Bahamas.{{cite web|url= http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/cg.htm|title= Commonwealth Games Medallists – Athletics (Men)|accessdate=17 May 2016}} Agostini won another gold in the [[1959 British West Indies Championships]] in the 100 m and a bronze in the 200 m.{{cite web|url= http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/bwic.htm |title= British West Indies Championships |accessdate=17 May 2016}} Agostini had also represented Trinidad and Tobago at the [[Athletics at the 1956 Summer Olympics – Men's 100 metres|Men's 100 m]] and [[Athletics at the 1956 Summer Olympics – Men's 200 metres|Men's 200 m]] at the [[1956 Summer Olympics]], ranking 6th and 4th, respectively.{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/summer/1956/ATH/mens-100-metres.html|title=Athletics at the 1956 Melbourne Summer Games: Men's 100 metres |accessdate=17 May 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/summer/1956/ATH/mens-200-metres.html |title= Athletics at the 1956 Melbourne Summer Games: Men's 200 metres |accessdate=17 May 2016}} ==Post-retirement== Agostini retired from active sports in the late 1950s. He graduated with a degree in [[economics]] from [[Fresno State University]], California, in 1958. In the late 1950s Agostini moved to Australia and married Pamela, with whom he had two daughters and two sons.{{cite web|url=http://www.iaaf.org/news/iaaf-news/mike-agostini-obituary |title=Trinidadian sprint legend Agostini dies |work=[[International Association of Athletics Federations]] |date= 12 May 2016 |accessdate=16 May 2016}} He received Australian citizenship in 1961. He coached various sprinters, including [[Ralph Doubell]], [[Andrew Ratcliffe]], [[Peter Vassella]], and [[Jenny Lamy]]. He worked as a freelance journalist and as a teacher for a brief time, and also served as editor and publisher for ''Track and Field'' magazine in the mid-1960s. He edited numerous periodicals and authored nine books. In 2007, Mike Agostini was inducted into the [[Fresno County Athletic Hall of Fame]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.fresnoahof.org/current-past-inductees|title=Fresno County Athletic Hall of Fame {{!}} Home|website=Fresno County Athletic Hall of Fame {{!}} Home|access-date=2 February 2017}} In his later years, he suffered from [[arthritis]] and [[pancreatic cancer]]. He died on 12 May 2016 of cancer in Sydney. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} == External links == {{Commons category|Mike Agostini}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150514030304/http://www.sportarchivestt.com/athletes/michael-agostini/ Profile at sportarchivestt.com] * [http://www.bestoftrinidad.com/olympics/agostini.html Profile] at ''Best of Trinidad'' {{Footer Commonwealth Champions 100 metres Men}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Agostini, Mike}} [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:2016 deaths]] [[Category:Trinidad and Tobago male sprinters]] [[Category:Australian sportswriters]] [[Category:Australian businesspeople]] [[Category:Athletes (track and field) at the 1954 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]] [[Category:Athletes (track and field) at the 1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]] [[Category:Athletes (track and field) at the 1955 Pan American Games]] [[Category:Athletes (track and field) at the 1959 Pan American Games]] [[Category:Athletes (track and field) at the 1956 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic athletes of Trinidad and Tobago]] [[Category:Commonwealth Games medallists in athletics]] [[Category:Commonwealth Games gold medallists for Trinidad and Tobago]] [[Category:Commonwealth Games bronze medallists for Trinidad and Tobago]] [[Category:Pan American Games silver medalists for Trinidad and Tobago]] [[Category:Pan American Games bronze medalists for Trinidad and Tobago]] [[Category:Pan American Games silver medalists for the British West Indies]] [[Category:Pan American Games bronze medalists for the British West Indies]] [[Category:Pan American Games medalists in athletics (track and field)]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in New South Wales]] [[Category:Track and field athletes from California]] [[Category:Fresno State Bulldogs athletes]]

'''Naum Alexandrovich Babaev''' ({{lang-ru|Наум Александрович Бабаев}}, [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]]: nɐ′um ɐlʲɪk′sandrɐvitɕ bɐ′baʲef) is a Russian entrepreneur, the founder of the Russian dairy company Rusmolco, a major raw milk producer, and the co-founder and joint owner of DAMATÉ group, a large agricultural holding specialising in poultry farming, dairy farming, and milk processing.
== Education and career == Naum Babaev was born in [[Kislovodsk]], [[Stavropol Krai]] on March 17, 1977, into the family of Rosa Michailovna and Alexander Naumovich Babaev.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acdamate.com/en/naum-babaev|title=Naum Babaev|publisher=DAMATE Group/Группа компаний "Дамате"|accessdate=19 February 2018}}</ref>
Аfter finishing high school in 1994, Naum entered the Financial Academy under the Government of the Russian Federation and graduated in 1999. Being a college undergraduate, he started off as a financial analyst at Cherkizovsky,<ref name="Moscow Times 2014">{{Cite news|url=https://themoscowtimes.com/articles/qa-farming-pioneer-babayev-milks-at-520-cows-per-hour-32550|title=Farming Pioneer Babayev Milks at 520 Cows Per Hour|last=|first=|date=February 27, 2014|work=The Moscow Times|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> a major Russian meat processing plant, which was subsequently reorganized into a JSC Group [[Cherkizovo]], Russia’s largest producer of meat products.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thepoultrysite.com/poultrynews/39141/cherkizovo-group-ranks-as-russias-top-meat-producer/|title=Cherkizovo Group Ranks as Russia's Top Meat Producer|last=|first=|date=11 September 2017|work=The Poultry site|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
In 2000, Babaev took over as a head of the poultry production business unit in the company’s agro-industrial complex and was managing it until 2005, when, due to the merger of the company’s agro-industrial and meat processing units, a larger facility was formed, namely CHERKIZOVO Group; Naum was appointed the company’s Strategy and Development Director.
According to Vedomosti, the prominent Russian business daily, his achievements at the position were fully recognized with CHERKIZOVO’s IPO launch in 2006.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/newspaper/article/2007/01/17/119091/|title=Москва. Бабаев покинул "Черкизово"|last=|first=|date=17 January 2007|work="Ведомости"|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/newspaper/article/2008/11/20/169918/|title=Снова в деревню|last=|first=|date=20 December 2008|work="Ведомости"|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
At the beginning of 2007, Babaev resigned to proceed on his own. Cherkizovo’s official statement marked his contribution to the Group.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cherkizovo.com/en/press/company-news/2163/|title=Management change in Cherkizovo Group|last=|first=|date=16 January 2007|website=Cherkizovo.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Business == Rusmolco was established in October 2007, when Babaev started two mega dairy farms, from the ground up in [[Penza Oblast]] about 700 km south-east of Moscow.<ref name=":1" /><ref name="Moscow Times 2014" /> By 2011 Rusmolco had become a major regional raw milk producer, doubling the average milk productivity in Russia at 9270 kg per cow<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ym-penza.ru/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=310:ministerskij-vizit&Itemid=256|title=Министерский визит|last=|first=|date=29 April 2013|work="Улица Московская", Penza region|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> against the average 4500 kg, according to the data of the Ministry of Agriculture of the Russian Federation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dairynews.ru/news/vladimir-labinov-vpered-i-vverkh-.html|title=Владимир Лабинов: "...Вперед и вверх!". Интервью с директором Департамента животноводства и племенного дела Минсельхоза РФ|author=|first=|date=3 February 2014|work=DairyNews.ru, Москва|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
"Babayev has thrived on importing foreign best practices to Russian farms", said ''[[The Moscow Times]]''.<ref name="Moscow Times 2014"/>
At the beginning of 2012, Rusmolco embarked on a strategic cooperation with a Singapore company [[Olam International]], a leading agri-business, operating in 70 countries.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.agrimoney.com/news/olam-fuels-trading-house-rivalry-with-russia-deal-30521|title=Olam fuels trading house rivalry with Russia deal|last=|first=|date=30 January 2012|work=AgriMoney|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> OLAM invested $75 million in the deal, thereby attaining 75% of Rusmolco assets.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/olam-russia/singapores-olam-in-400-mln-russian-dairy-and-grains-partnership-idUSL4E8CU46320120130|title=Singapore's Olam in $400 mln Russian dairy and grains partnership|last=|first=|date=30 January 2012|work=Reuters|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> The partners announced their intention to form a large-scale dairy enterprise with $400 million investment capital (the initial 20-thousand milking herd was meant to reach up to 50 thousand heads in the short run).<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://themoscowtimes.com/articles/deal-makes-rusmolco-industry-leader-12257|title=Deal Makes Rusmolco Industry Leader|last=|first=|date=30 January 2012|work=The Moscow Times|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Thus, Russia’s agriculture secured a hefty chunk of investment, labeled in the mass media as being "unprecedented".<ref name=":3" />
In 2012, by a year-end estimation of the Institute for the Agricultural Market Studies, Rusmolco secured the fourth place among the five largest raw milk producers in the Russian Federation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.souzmoloko.ru/news/pressa-o-nas/pressa-o-nas_1631.html|title=Млечный путь|last=|first=|date=September 2013|work=RBC Magazine. The article posted on the website of the National Union of Milk Producers (Soyuzmoloko)|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
In 2011, shortly after the Olam International deal, Babaev undertook the effort to consolidate the leftover assets (namely, the turkey production plant, the PENZENSKY dairy complex as well as a veal-and-milk production facility in Penza and Tyumen regions, and 25K hectares of agricultural land.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=http://www.agroinvestor.ru/companies/article/12252-postroyat-rynok/|title=Построят рынок. "Дамате" создает производство 60 тыс. т индейки в год|last=|first=|date=July 2013|work=«Агроинвестор»|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> The effort had been a success, resulting in the launch of the agro-industrial holding company Damaté Group.
The Group’s priority was turkey meat production. At the time, turkey was not popular with the Russians; the average consumption per capita wobbled at 0, 8-1,0 kg, with the overall production hardly totaling 120-150 thousand tons per year.<ref name=":4" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.globalmeatnews.com/Article/2013/09/12/Rapid-growth-forecast-in-Russian-turkey-market|title=Rapid growth forecast in Russian turkey market|last=|first=|date=12 September 2013|work=Global MeatNews.com|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
By the end of 2016, Damaté became the largest turkey producing company in Russia.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.agroinvestor.ru/companies/news/24411-damate-obognala-evrodon-po-proizvodstvu-indeyki/|title="Дамате" обогнала "Евродон" по производству индейки|last=|first=|date=9 October 2016|work=«АгроИнвестор»|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.globalmeatnews.com/Headlines/Industry-Markets/Russia-s-largest-turkey-producer-sets-sights-on-expansion|title=Russia’s largest turkey producer sets sights on expansion|last=|first=|date=18 October 2017|work=Global MeatNews.com|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> According to the Agrifood Strategies data, in 2016, the company produced 60,800 tons of turkey in carcass weight.<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://www.vedomosti.ru/business/articles/2017/03/14/681014-damate-krupneishim-indeiki|title="Дамате" Наума Бабаева стала крупнейшим производителем индейки в России|last=|first=|date=14 March 2017|work=Ведомости|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> The Damaté leadership had also been confirmed by Rosptitsesoyuz, the Russian Union of Poultry Producers.<ref name=":5" />
According to Vedomosti, "In the 10 years' span, the entrepreneur Naum Babaev made a profound career leap, from the top-manager of a major agro-holding to the owner of the largest turkey producer in Russia".<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://www.vedomosti.ru/business/characters/2017/05/15/689912-naum-babaev|title="Мы не делаем ничего, что не едим сами"|last=|first=|date=16 May 2017|work=Ведомости|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
At the end of 2016, Damaté had been ranked among the top-25 largest meat producers in this country.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.agroinvestor.ru/analytics/article/28459-lidery-myasnoy-industrii-top-25-krupneyshikh-proizvoditeley-myasa/|title=Лидеры мясной индустрии. Топ-25 крупнейших производителей мяса|last=|first=|date=September 2017|work="АгроИнвестор"|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
In 2012, Babaev acquired the dairy product plant Penzensky (MOLCOM), the largest processor of milk in Penza region with a cheese factory in Belinsky town.
At the end of 2013, Damaté, in partnership with food group [[Danone Group|Danone]], launched a high-powered production of the premium quality milk in Tyumen region, Western Siberia.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-danone-russia/danone-to-invest-in-russian-dairy-farms-idUSBRE9A00DQ20131101|title=Danone to invest in Russian dairy farms|last=|first=|date=1 November 2013|work=Reuters|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.just-food.com/news/danone-damate-sign-co-finance-dairy-deal_id124998.aspx|title=RUSSIA: Danone, Damate sign co-finance dairy deal|last=|first=|date=4 November 2013|work=Just-food|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> At the beginning of 2017, Tyumen delivered its first tons of milk to Danone production facilities<ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.rusexporter.com/news/detail/5182/|title=One of the largest and most modern dairy complexes in Russia was opened in the Tyumen region|last=|first=|date=15 December 2017|work=Russian Exports National Information portal|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
Babaev owns Damaté on a par with the holding’s CEO Rashid Khairov. They had met in 1998, long before the Damaté endeavor. According to Vedomosti, in their current partnership, Babaev is implementing the strategic management of the firm, while Khairov is being responsible for the day-to-day management.<ref name=":6" />
== Personal life == Naum Babaev is married to Anna, a photographer; the family is raising three children,<ref name="Moscow Times 2014"/> Alexander (2006), Mikhail (2009), and Elizaveta (2013).

<!-- Image with inadequate rationale removed: [[Image:Tahitinui.png|right|thumb|Levy was the founder and first CEO of [[Air Tahiti Nui]].]] --> '''Nelson Lévy''' (born ? - died June 3, 2007 [[Tahiti]]) was a leading figure in French Polynesia [[tourism]] and the founding head of [[Air Tahiti Nui]], the [[national airline]] of [[French Polynesia]].
==Career== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Tahiti Tourisme Logo.jpg|right|thumb| Levy headed Tahiti Tourisme in the 1990s.]] --> Levy originally began reporting as a [[journalist]] in the 1970s.<ref name=Pacific>{{cite news |first= |last= |title=Nelson Levy, Tahiti Tourism Pioneer, Has Died |url=http://www.pacificmagazine.net/news/2007/06/05/nelson-levy-tahiti-tourism-pioneer-has-died |publisher=[[Pacific News Service]] |date=2007-06-05 |accessdate=2007-07-23 }}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> However, Levy soon changed careers and began working in French Polynesia's booming [[tourism industry]].
In January 1992 Levy took over the [[management]] as head of [[Tahiti]] Tourism Promotion Office, which was the French Polynesia's main tourism [[marketing]] and information agency.<ref name=Nui>{{cite news |first=|last=|title= Air Tahiti Nui Press Release: Nelson Lévy, Founder of Air Tahiti Nui and one of Tahiti's modern tourism pioneers, dies at age 58 |url= http://www.airtahitinui-usa.com/company/presscontent.asp?id=77|work= [[Air Tahiti Nui]] press release |publisher= |date=2007-06-05 |accessdate=2007-07-23 }}</ref> Levy helped transform the office into the present day [[GIE Tahiti Tourisme]].<ref name=Nui/> [[Tahiti Tourism]] is based in [[Papeete]] and currently operates a worldwide promotional and [[advertising campaign]] called, [[Tahiti and Her Islands]].<ref name=Nui/> Levy left Tahiti Tourisme in August 1998 to become the first [[CEO]] of Air Tahiti Nui.<ref name=Nui/>
Levy helped found [[Air Tahiti Nui]] in 1996 as French Polynesia's international airline. The airline launched its first international flights in 1998, the same year that Levy became Air Tahiti Nui's first [[CEO]].<ref name=Nui/> Levy helped to guide the international expansion of the airline while CEO and earned a reputation for his managerial efficiency. As CEO of Air Tahiti Nui, Levy was nominated in 2002 by [[Travel Agent Magazine]] for "Manager of the Year" in the [[Asia Pacific]] region.<ref name=Pacific/>
Levy was very well connected in the tourism industry, as well as in [[Politics of French Polynesia|French Polynesian politics]]. Levy was a prominent supporter of the [[Tahoeraa Huiraatira|Tahoeraa Huiraatira Party]], a pro-French political party which opposes independence for French Polynesia from [[France]].<ref name=Pacific/> He was replaced as CEO of the airline when the coalition of pro-independence parties led by [[Oscar Temaru]] took power in a surprise election victory. However, Levy returned to the board of directors of Air Tahiti Nui following the 2005 presidential election win of French Polynesian President [[Gaston Tong Sang]], a pro-French candidate from the Tahoeraa Huiraatira Party.<ref name=Pacific/> Sang asked Levy back to help revive the ailing airline, which was suffering from "recurrent" financial shortfalls and problems.<ref name=Pacific/> (The [[Government of French Polynesia]] is a 61.7% [[shareholder]] in the airline.)
Additionally, Levy also served as head of the local French Polynesian post and [[telecommunications]] company, OPT.<ref name=Pacific/>
Levy's last tourism venture was the June 1, 2007, launch of '''easyTahiti.com''' [http://easyTahiti.com], a specialist travel [[web site]] for [[Tahiti]] and other French Polynesian islands.<ref name=Nui/> EasyTahiti.com has been described as "Tahiti's biggest virtual travel agency" in a [[press release]] from Air Tahiti Nui.<ref name=Nui/>
==Death== Nelson Levy died unexpectedly of a [[heart attack]] on June 3, 2007, at his home in Tahiti,<ref name=Nui/> just two days after the official [[soft launch|launch]] of easyTahiti.com. Levy had hosted [[barbecue]] for employees of easyTahiti.com at his home just hours before his death.<ref name=Nui/> His funeral took place in [[Papeete, Tahiti]] on June 6, 2007.<ref name=Pacific/> Levy was survived by his wife, Vaea, and two daughters, Vaiarava and Poerava.<ref name=Nui/>
==External links== *[http://www.airtahitinui-usa.com/company/presscontent.asp?id=77 Air Tahiti Nui Press Release: Nelson Lévy, Founder of Air Tahiti Nui and one of Tahiti's modern tourism pioneers, dies at age 58] *[http://www.pacificmagazine.net/news/2007/06/05/nelson-levy-tahiti-tourism-pioneer-has-died Pacific Magazine: Nelson Levy, Tahiti Tourism Pioneer, Has Died]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *[http://easytahiti.com/ easyTahiti.com] *[http://www.airtahitinui-usa.com/ Air Tahiti Nui U.S. Web Site] *[http://www.tahiti-tourisme.com/ Tahiti Tourisme Official Site]

The '''Petroleum Institute of Thailand (PTIT)''' is a non-profit organisation supporting the upstream oil and gas industry as well as the downstream petroleum and [[petrochemical industry]] in [[Thailand]].
== History ==
The Petroleum Institute of Thailand was founded on 26 September 1985 with support from the government, academic, industrial and private sector interests.<ref>[http://www.ptit.org/index.php/About.History/History History of the Petroleum Institute of Thailand.]</ref> It is directed by the Foundation Board, the Advisory Board to the Council of Trustees and the Council of Trustees, which control the Institute's operations and give advice on financing the Institute's wide range of activities.
From 1985 to 2005 [[Khunying Thongtip Ratanarat]] was Executive Director of the institute. Now the Foundation Board and Advisory Board to the Council of Trustees are chaired by [[Privy Councilor]] Kamthon Sindhvanada.
== Mission ==
The institute encourages and supports the development of the petroleum, petrochemical and related industries. It provides human resource development services and information services. It supports research and development in industry and encourages an open dialogue between the government, industry and academia for establishing practical public policies and regulations as well as prudent industry standards and best practices.
The work of the institute is related to public policies and regulations:<ref>[http://www.ptit.org/index.php/Committees/PTIT-Standing-Committees Standing Committees of the Petroleum Institute of Thailand.]</ref> * Exploration and production * Refining & petrochemical processing * Logistics and marketing
The institute communicates proactively with the public to facilitate a mutual understanding and to strengthen the public image of the industry. It acts as an impartial and independend know-how provider and fosters the continuous competitiveness and sustainability of the petroleum and petrochemical industry especially in the areas of health, safety and environment as well as operations.

{{Use British (Oxford) English|date=April 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Insolvency}} A '''preferential creditor''' (in some [[jurisdiction]]s called a '''preferred creditor''') is a [[creditor]] receiving a preferential right to payment upon the debtor's [[bankruptcy]] under applicable insolvency laws.
In most legal systems, some creditors are given priority over ordinary creditors, either for the whole amount of their claims or up to a certain value. In some legal systems, preferential creditors take priority over all other creditors, including creditors holding [[security interest|security]], but more commonly, the preferential creditors are only given priority over [[unsecured creditor]]s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Liquidation: a guide for creditors|url=http://www.asic.gov.au/asic/pdflib.nsf/LookupByFileName/Liquidation_guide_for_creditors.pdf/$file/Liquidation_guide_for_creditors.pdf|publisher=Australian Securities & Investments Commission|accessdate=29 July 2014}}</ref> Some legal systems operate a hybrid approach; in the [[United Kingdom]] preferential creditors have priority over [[secured creditor]]s whose security is in the nature of a [[floating charge]], but creditors with fixed security take ahead of the preferential creditors generally.
In [[English law]] the concept was first introduced for personal bankruptcy in 1825 pursuant to the [[Bankrupts (England) Act 1825]], and for companies in 1888 pursuant to the [[Preferential Payments in Bankruptcy Act 1888]]. Prior to that, all [[unsecured creditor]]s ranked equally and without preference ("''[[pari passu]]''") in a series of statutes stretching back to the [[Statute of Bankrupts|Statute of Bankrupts 1542]].
==Classes of preferred creditors==<!-- [[First class creditor]], [[Second class creditor]], [[Privileged creditor]], and [[Third class creditor]] redirect here -->
Creditors who are characteristically preferred creditors are: * [[employee]]s: If a company goes bankrupt, the employees of that company will be first in line to be paid. If the company owes wages, this is considered to be the top priority when it comes to dissolving the company. * [[tax|revenue authorities]]: When a government is owed taxes, they are on the top of the list to get paid. * in some countries, [[tort]] victims: The rationale for tort victims is that they are perceived to be "involuntary" creditors of the bankrupt and thus should not be penalised by an insolvency in the same manner as parties who voluntarily became creditors of the bankrupt. * in some countries, environmental clean-up costs: If a business files for bankruptcy and it is determined that they need to clean up the environment as a result of their business actions, the environmental clean up will get preferential treatment. The courts will allocate a designated amount of money to pay for the cleanup efforts.<ref>{{cite web|title=4 Types of Preferential Creditors|url=http://www.finweb.com/loans/4-types-of-preferential-creditors.html#axzz38pHy3eR3|accessdate=29 July 2014}}</ref>
In the United Kingdom, employees’ holiday pay/wages are classed as preferential – if they are paid via [[redundancy payments]] fund then the [[Department of Employment]] becomes a secured creditor. If there is a shortfall, in those cases where someone earns in excess of the government limit, then they can claim preferentially too. <ref>{{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=Mike|title=Company Liquidation: A Directors’ Guide to a Creditors’ Voluntary Liquidation|url=http://www.companydebt.com/liquidation/creditors-voluntary-liquidation/directors-guide|accessdate=24 July 2014}}</ref> The right of the Crown as a preferential creditor was removed by the [[Enterprise Act 2002]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Enterprise Act 2002|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2002/40/contents|website=Legislation.gov.uk|publisher=The Crown of United Kingdom}}</ref>
Creditors, and sometimes individual assets, are also placed in classes by specific laws for specific events, such as a [[deposit insurance]] scheme triggered by a bank failure. For example, [[Switzerland]]'s deposit protection has Class I (first-class), Class II (second-class) and Class III (third-class) unsecured creditors.<ref>[http://www.einlagensicherung.ch/en/home.htm Einlagensicherung]. ''Deposit Protection of Swiss Banks and Securities Dealers''. Retrieved 2008-10-09 (English)</ref> following are the preferential creditors:- 1.all revenues, taxes, cesses and rates, whether payable to the Government or local authority, due to payment by the company with in 12 months before the date of commencement of winding up.<ref>{{cite web|title=Companies Act 1956|url=http://www.mca.gov.in/Ministry/actsbills/pdf/Companies_Act_1956_Part_1.pdf|publisher=Government of India: Ministry of Corporate Affairs|accessdate=29 July 2014|date=18 Jan 1956}}</ref>
==Admiralty claims== In [[admiralty law]], many legal systems accord certain claims preferential status where a ship is subject to arrest. These claims vary from country to country, but commonly include: * [[marine salvage|salvage]] claims * seaman's wages * moorage fees: Cost of mooring is often a preferential claim of expediency. Otherwise it would be difficult to arrange mooring for vessels which are subject to arrest.
